questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following cranial nerves are affected in cavernous sinus syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The cranial nerves III, IV, V, and VI are affected by cavernous sinus syndrome. The cavernous sinus syndrome is a condition caused by any pathology involving the cavernous 
sinus. The oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV) and trigeminal (V) nerves pass in relation to the lateral 
wall of the cavernous sinus. The abducent (VI) nerve passes through the cavernous sinus. Patients with this condition usually present with the following features: • Orbital or facial pain • Orbital swelling and chemosis due to occlusion of the ophthalmic veins • Fever • Oculomotor neuropathy (III, IV, and VI) • Trigeminal neuropathy (V) Causes of cavernous sinus syndrome include: • Cavernous sinus thrombosis - most common • Carotid artery aneurysm • Carotid-cavernous fistula • Tumors such as meningioma. 1256 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is true regarding trigeminal neuralgia?

options.a: The region of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve is always spared
options.b: The pain usually last for a few hours
options.c: The condition is also known as tic douloureux
options.d: It is more common in men

questions.explanation:
Tic douloureux is another term for trigeminal neuralgia. Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by frequent paroxysms of severe pain in the lips, gums, 
cheek, or chin. It is sometimes seen in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the 
trigeminal nerve. Middle-aged and elderly females are primarily affected. The pain usually lasts for a short time 
(seconds to minutes) but be may intense enough that the patient winces, hence the term 'tic'. A characteristic feature is the presence of trigger zones, typically on the face, lips, or tongue. 
Patients usually report excruciating pain during activities such as washing the face or brushing the 
teeth. However, no signs of sensory loss can be demonstrated.

questions.question:
Question 3: The high frequency of trigeminal neuralgia in patients with multiple sclerosis is mainly 
attributed to the involvement of  
.

options.a: Oligodendrocyte-derived myelin covering the beginning of the nerve
options.b: Oligodendrocyte-derived myelin covering the terminal part of the nerve
options.c: Schwann cell–derived myelin sheath covering the beginning of the nerve
options.d: Schwann cell–derived myelin sheath covering the terminal part of the nerve

questions.explanation:
The high frequency of trigeminal neuralgia in patients with multiple sclerosis occurs due to the 
involvement of oligodendrocyte-derived myelin covering the beginning of the nerve. Multiple sclerosis is a disorder of oligodendrocyte myelin. It should be ruled out when trigeminal 
neuralgia is bilateral or develops in a young adult. In such cases, the cause is a demyelinating 
plaque near the root entry zone of the fifth cranial nerve in the pons. In these patients, a facial 
sensory loss is also often found in association.

questions.question:
Question 4: In patients with trigeminal neuralgia, the nerve is most commonly compressed by  
.
questions.explanation:
1257 
Sold by @itachibot The superior cerebellar artery most often compresses the trigeminal nerve as it emerges from the 
brainstem. This causes lancinating pain in the distribution of the nerve which is known 
as trigeminal neuralgia. Though trigeminal neuralgia can be diagnosed by the clinical features, MRI is recommended to 
define the underlying cause. In cases refractory to medical management, it also helps to plan for 
surgical decompression.

questions.question:
Question 5: A food vlogger presents with complaints of episodes of piercing electric-shock like pain on the 
left side of her face. The episodes are triggered by chewing food and last for a few minutes. 
She is further distressed as it interferes with her work. She has tried over the counter 
analgesics to no avail. What is the drug of choice for her?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia and the drug of choice 
is carbamazepine. Oxcarbazepine is an alternative to carbamazepine that has less bone marrow toxicity and is 
equally efficacious. Other drugs used are lamotrigine, gabapentin and baclofen.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is false about Bell's palsy?

options.c: MRI shows enhancement of geniculate ganglion

questions.explanation:
Maximal weakness occurs within 48 hours as a rule in Bells' palsy. Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower 
motor neuron (LMN) lesion of the facial nerve. Clinical presentation of Bell’s palsy: • Pain behind the ear (may precede paralysis and last for 1-2 days) • Bell's phenomenon • Asymmetrical face • Hyperacusis (due to stapedial paralysis) • Loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). MRI may reveal swelling and uniform enhancement of the geniculate ganglion and facial nerve. Approximately 80% of patients recover within a few weeks or months. The presence of incomplete 
paralysis in the first week is the most favorable prognostic sign. Recurrence may be seen in some 
cases.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following viruses is most commonly implicated in Bell’s palsy?
questions.explanation:
Herpes simplex virus is most commonly implicated in causing Bell’s palsy. Varicella-zoster virus is the second most common cause. 1258 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is true about Bell’s phenomenon?

options.a: Eyeballs roll upwards on attempting to open the eyes
options.b: Eyeballs roll downwards on attempting to close the eyes
options.c: It is a normal phenomenon evident in facial paralysis
options.d: It is an abnormal phenomenon evident in facial paralysis

questions.explanation:
Bell’s phenomenon refers to a normal phenomenon that becomes evident in facial paralysis. The 
eyeballs roll up and outwards on attempting to close the eyes. It is also known as the palpebral oculogyric reflex. It is a normal protective reflex resulting in the 
elevation of globes while blinking to protect the eyes from injury. It also serves to provide a wiper 
blade-like cleansing function of the cornea by the eyelid. However, it occurs behind the closed eyelids in healthy individuals. It becomes noticeable in Bell's 
palsy as the eyelids fail to close completely. The image below shows a patient with evident Bell’s phenomenon.

questions.question:
Question 9: On returning from work, a man noticed that his mother had developed mild right-sided facial 
drooping. Believing it to be due to a stroke, he immediately took her to the hospital. After 
extensive evaluation, the doctor ruled out stroke and diagnosed her with Bell's palsy. Which 
of the following would not be a part of the management of her condition?

options.a: Paper tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep
options.b: Prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days

questions.explanation:
Acyclovir may be considered as add-on therapy for patients with severe Bell's palsy as 400mg five 
times daily for 10 days. Monotherapy is not recommended. Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then 
tapered over the next 5 days. Randomized trials found no added benefit of the antiviral agents 
valacyclovir and acyclovir when compared to glucocorticoids alone. The use of paper tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep prevents corneal drying. For patients with permanent paralysis, cosmetic surgical procedures have been used to restore a 
relatively symmetric appearance to the face.

Question 11: Identify the correct type of facial nerve palsy in the following patients based on their clinical 
features:
questions.explanation:
Patient 1 has left UMN facial nerve palsy and patient 2 has right LMN facial nerve palsy. In an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, wrinkling on the forehead and eyelid closure remains 
intact. In this lesion, the contralateral side of the face is affected. The first-order neurons from 1260 
Sold by @itachibot the left cerebral hemisphere cross over (left to right) at the cortical level and relay in 
the right facial nerve nucleus in the pons. From here the second-order neurons (right facial nerve) 
descend and supply the right side of the face. Hence, a left UMN lesion causes paralysis of the lower half of the face on the right side. In facial 
palsy, the angle of the mouth deviates towards the normal side. In this patient, since the mouth 
deviates towards the left, the right facial nerve is affected. In lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions, there is an absence of wrinkling on the forehead and

questions.question:
Question 13: You are evaluating a woman with unilateral facial weakness. However, you notice forehead 
wrinkling is intact. On examination, which of the following findings would you not expect?
questions.explanation:
The given features are suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion of the facial nerve in 
which the emotional response is affected. Patients with UMN lesions of the facial nerve have 
emotional incontinence i.e. involuntary, uncontrollable laughter, or crying with a paradoxical 
deficit of facial expression. Normally cerebellum modulates motor outputs in response to sensory inputs. UMN facial palsy 
(type of pseudobulbar palsy) is associated with disruption of cortico-ponto-cerebellar pathways 
leading to loss of cerebellar modulation resulting in: • Emotional dysmetria (difficulty in fine-tuning emotional responses) • Emotional disinhibition (excessive emotional output) Difference between UMN and LMN facial palsy: Feature

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following statements is true about facial synkinesis?

options.a: Refers to simultaneous bilateral facial nerve palsy
options.b: Refers to facial nerve palsy associated with trigeminal neuralgia
options.c: Occurs due to anomalous regeneration of the facial nerve fibers
options.d: Loss of emotional response is seen in this condition

questions.explanation:
Facial synkinesis occurs due to anomalous regeneration of facial nerve fibers. Following facial nerve injury , the recovering nerve fibers may aberrantly regenerate and supply 
other muscles. This results in involuntary muscular movements in the face during voluntary facial 
movements. 1262 
Sold by @itachibot Some examples include: • Retraction of the mouth on closure of the eyelids: • Seen when fibers originally connected with the orbicularis oculi aberrantly innervate the 
orbicularis oris • 'Crocodile tears' also known as Bogorad syndrome: • It refers to anomalous tearing occurring with activity of the facial muscles, such as eating. • Due to aberrant innervation of the lacrimal gland. Note: Frey's syndrome is an aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and the 
great auricular nerve, resulting in gustatory sweating.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is false regarding hemifacial spasm?

options.a: The contractions are painful and irregular
options.b: It is a complication of Bell's palsy
options.d: Local injection of botulinum toxin is effective

questions.explanation:
Hemifacial spasms are painless irregular contractions occurring on one side of the face. They commonly occur as sequelae to Bell's palsy. It can also be seen in irritative lesions of the 
facial nerve such as acoustic neuroma and basilar aneurysm. Treatment is with carbamazepine or gabapentin. In resistant cases, baclofen may be tried. Local 
injection of botulinum toxin and surgical decompression are alternative options.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following are features of Melkerrson-Rosenthal syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome is a rare disease characterised by the following triad: • Recurrent facial nerve palsy • Facial edema (particularly labial) • Plication of tongue or fissured tongue 1263 
Sold by @itachibot Facial paralysis along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna is seen 
in Ramsay-Hunt syndrome. It occurs due to herpes zoster infection and is also called herpes 
zoster oticus. Congenital facial weakness combined with abnormal ocular abduction is seen in Moebius 
syndrome. Patients may present with bilateral concurrent facial nerve paralysis.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 70-year-old man presented with complaints of sudden stabs of pain in the throat on 
yawning. Each episode only lasted for a few seconds and was exacerbated on trying to clear 
the throat. Which of the following findings can you see on examination?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features are suggestive of glossopharyngeal neuralgia which is associated with cardiac 
symptoms such as bradycardia, asystole, hypotension, and fainting. It involves the glossopharyngeal (IX) and sometimes portions of the vagus (X) nerve. The 
condition resembles trigeminal neuralgia but is less common. There is no demonstrable sensory 
or motor deficit. It can result from vascular compression, multiple sclerosis or tumors. The drug of choice is carbamazepine. If unsuccessful, surgical procedures are indicated: • Microvascular decompression (if vascular compression is evident) • Rhizotomy of glossopharyngeal and vagal fibers in the jugular bulb 1264 
Sold by @itachibot Infections of the Nervous System
